questionText: A 12-year-old girl was rushed to the emergency unit with the history of seizures and fever. The Nurse on assessment discovered an infected uleer on the right leg. Which of the following could be the possible diagnosis

questionText: 15 year old Nephrotic syndrome patient is on furosemide. Which of the following electrolytes would be depleted in this patient?
rationale: Furosemide is a loop diuretic medication that is commonly used in the treatment of oedema and fluid overload in patients with nephrotic syndrome. One of the major side effects of furosemide is the loss of electrolytes, particularly potassium, through increased urine output.

questionText: A 16 year old SHS boy was brought to your facility by the mother who complained of detecting some changes in his physical appearance with age. During Physical assessment of the patient, you noticed Clubbing of his fingers. Patient is likely to be diagnosed of having?
rationale: Clubbing of fingers is a medical condition where the fingertips enlarge and round at the nail base, due to increased tissue growth and changes in blood flow. Clubbing of fingers is a common physical sign of congenital heart disease and is a result of increased blood flow and oxygenation in the fingertips.

questionText: What is/are the typical fest symptom(s) of myasthenia gravis?
rationale: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that affects the transmission of nerve impulses to the muscles, resulting in muscle weakness and fatigue. questionText: A 26 year old man was rushed to the hospital by relatives who complained that patient sustained a cut on the left ankle while weeding his backyard two (2) weeks ago. rationale: Tetanus is a life-threatening infection caused by Clostridium tetani that affects the nervous system and presents with symptoms such as muscle stuffness, spasms, fever, sweating, rapid heart rate, high blood pressure, difficulty swallowing, and breathing.

questionText: A 26-year-old female with no past medical history presents with a low-grade fever, dysuria, and flank pain. She is diagnosed with pyelonephritis. What is the most likely causative pathogen in this case?
rationale: The most likely causative pathogen for pyelonephritis, which is an infection of the kidney, in a young, healthy female with dysuria and flank pain is Escherichia coli, which is the most common causative organism in community-acquired urinary tract infections.

questionText: A 26-year-old man reports at your facility with complains of a painless penile lesion for several weeks and recent swelling in the groin. rationale: Paunary syphilis is characterized by the development of a painless ulcer at the site of infection and bilateral non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is a common finding, which helps to differentiate it from other causes of genital ulcers. Moreover, a negative lePR test does not rule out syphilis.

questionText: A 28-year-old female patient complains of vaginal discharge associated with burning, irritation, and pruritus. rationale: Candidiasis is the most com infectious cause of vulvovaginal pruritus, as it is s fungal infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida yeast, which is normally present in the vagina, and can cause symptoms such as itching burning, and thick white discharge.

questionText: A 29-year-old man is on achoussion on your ward He complains of chest pain and ditticuity breathing His past medical history is asthma, for which he takes albuterol when needed Vital signe checked and recorded as: blood pressure 110/80 mm Hu pulse rate of 140 beats per minunte, and oxygen saturation of 90% on room ans A physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds on the right side of the chestibu no crackles, wheezes, or thouchi. rationale: A chest radiograph is the best initial investigation to confirm the diagnosis of pneumothorax because it can visualize the presence of air in the pleural space, which is characteristic of pneumothorax and allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questionText: A 30 year old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia presents with a complaint of double vision that increases in the evening. She also had difficult swallowing food over the past month. She takes no medications and does not drink or smoke. She was diagnosed as having Myastinia Gravis. rationale: Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disorder that affects the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue. Pyridostigmine is the medication of choice to treat myasthenia gravis because it increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, improving neuromuscular transmission and reducing muscle weakness and fatigue.

questionText: A 30-year-old businessman was rushed to the emergency unit with the history of sudden loss of consciousness. Patient is to be catheterized for urine specimen to be collected as well as retained till patient gains consciousness. What measures would the murse take to prevent infecting the patient? I. Avoid unnecessary handling or manipulation of the catheter. II Ensure routine irrigation of the indwelling catheter. III. Empty the collection bag at least every 8 hours through the drainage spout. IV. use pre-assembled, sterile, closed urinary drainage system.
rationale: Routine irrigation of the indwelling catheter is not recommended, as it can increase the risk of infection and is not considered best practice. Instead, the catheter should only be irrigated when necessary, and this should be done using sterile technique.

questionText: A 30-year-old man is on admission with glomerulonephritis. His vital signs cheeked and recorded. Which of the following readings will indicate that he is having high blood pressure?
rationale: Diastolic pressure is the bottom number of a blood pressure reading, and a normal diastolic pressure is usually around 80 mm/Hg. A diastolic pressure of $90~mm/Hg$ or higher is considered high blood pressure, or hypertension.

questionText: A 32-year-old woman reported for a review. She has read about Graves' disease online and is afraid she has the diagnosis. Which of the following is specific to Graves' disease?
rationale: It is a specific symptom of Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder that affects the thyroid gland and leads to an overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism), and i characterized by eye disease, such as bulging of the eyes (exophthalmos), dryness, irritation, and un severe cases, double vision or vision loss.

questionText: A 34-year-old female presented to the emergency unit after waking up with unilateral facial paralysis On physical examination, she has flattening of her forehead and nasolabial fold on the affected side, difficulty closing her eyelid, and a tingling sensation on that side as well, With your knowledge about the nervous system and its functions, which cranial nerve is responsible for her condition?
rationale: The patient's symptoms suggest involvement of cranial nerve V (trigeminal nerve) as it is responsible for the innervation of the museles of facial expression and sensation on the face, and any damage to this nerve can result in facial paralysis, flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold, difficulty closing the eyelid, and a tingling sensation

questionText: A 39-year-old female is on admission with a diagnosis of severe hypertension which is controlled with a beta-blocker and a thiazide diuretic. Her history also indicates she has type 2 diabetes, for which she is currently taking an oral hypoglycemic agent and is controlled. Her urinalysis reveals microscopic proteinuria but blood pressure seems not to settle. What is the MOST appropriate treatment to be added to her management?
rationale: An ACE inhibitor (angiotensin- converting enzyme inhibitor) is a medication commonly used in the treatment of hypertension, and it has been shown to be effective in reducing proteinuria in patients with diabetes. It can help to reduce blood pressure further, protect the kidneys, and prevent or slow down the progression of diabetic nephropathy.

questionText: A 39-year-old man presents with epigastric fullness and discomfort that worsen after meals. His history taken indicates that he smokes but has no prior diagnosis of ulcer disease. Which of the following is the best diagnostic approach?

Empiric antimicrobial treatment of H. pylori.
Initial 8-week trial of a proton-pump inhibitor (PPI).
rationale: This is because this is the first-line diagnostic and treatment approach for most patients with dyspepsia, which is the presenting symptom. If the symptoms improve with the PPI trial, then the patient is unlikely to have an ulcer, and further investigation is unnecessary.

questionText: A 3-year old Musa Abdul is on admission with a valvular heart disease. In which of the valvular heart diseases can there he a backward flow of blood? I. Valvular Prolapse. II. Valvular regurgitation. III. Valvular Stenosis.
rationale: Valvular prolapse is the abnormal bulging of a heart valve leaflet, which can cause valve regurgitation; valvular regurgitation is the backward flow of blood through an improperly closing valve, decreasing heart efficiency, and valvular stenosis is the narrowing of a heart valve, impeding forward blood flow and leading to decreased cardiac output.

questionText: A 52-year-old woman has been referred by urologiat for a 3 cm right adrenal mass which was detected on abdominal scan. Her weight has been stable. questionText: A 53-year-old man with a history of chronic pancreatitis secondary to chronic alcohol use disorder on admission on your ward is complaining of acute worsening of epigastric pain and dizziness. His chronic pain has been hard to control despite adequate pain medications. On examination, he is afebrile, orthostatic, and has malena stool. Which of the following care is MOST appropriate?

rationale: The patient is presenting with new symptoms of acute worsening of epigastric pain and dizziness, which may indicate a more severe complication of pancreatitis, such as pancreatic necrosis on haemorrhage, and the presence of melena stool suggests potential gastrointestinal bleeding, therefore observing changes in vital signs. stool and vomitus and promptly reporting them is the most appropriate nursing intervention.

questionText: A 54-year-old Madam Afua Nartey is on admission on account of heart failure. During her care she complained of difficulty in breathing. rationale: To assess for abnormal breath sounds or congestion, auscultation of the lungs should be performed, along with positioning reduce pressure on the diaphragm to improve lung expansion, and administration of oxygen to improve oxygenation and reduce respiratory distress.

questionText: A 55 year old man presents with confusion und fever. He had an acute infero posterior myocardial infarction and underwent coronary angioplasty to: the right coronary artery. He is tebrile. He is disoriented to place and times His heart rate is 85 bpm, and his BP 95/73 mmHg. He had a short tonio- clonic seizure while doing examining the patient physically. Although his postictal state lasts an hour, no focal neurologic abnormalities are detected on repeated neurologis examinations. Brain CT is unremarkable. Laboratory studies reveal the following hematocrit 24%, white blood cells. 7.100/mm3. platelets $11,000/mm3,$ prothrombin time 12 seconds, partial thromboplastin time 31 seconds, blood urea nitrogen $21~mg/dL$ serum creatinine $2.9~mg/dL$, lactate dehydrogenase 900 U/L, and direct Coombs' test negative. rationale: These findings raise the suspicion of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), which is a medical emergency that requires urgent diagnosis and treatment. The next step in making a diagnosis in this case would be Peripheral blood smear review. A peripheral blood smear can help identify red blood cell fragments, known as schistocytes, which are characteristic of TTP.

questionText: A 55-year-old female patient has stage Il hypertension. On exam, she has trace pedal edema bilaterally but her lungs are clear. Her ECG reveals second-degree heart block. Which of the following medications should be avoided?
rationale: They should be avoided in this patient due to their potential to worsen the second-degree heart block as seen in the ECG. questionText: A 55years old banker was admitted to the ward with diagnosis of acute cardiac tamponade. What is the MOST important intervention?
rationale: The most important intervention in acute cardiac tamponade is to relieve the compression on the heart caused by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac. This is typically achieved by draining the fluid with a pericardiocentesis procedure

questionText: A 56 year old woman was admitted to the female ward with polydipsia, Kussmaal respiration, fruity odour, polyuria. She was disorientated and confused. How would this woman be diagnosed?
rationale: The symptoms described are characteristic of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of diabetes that occurs when the body produces high levels of blood acids called ketones due to insulin deficiency, and a blood test measuring ketone levels can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

questionText: A 56-year-old Kwame Quarshie has been diagnosed of having gout. In explaining the cause to him, you would mention that you as a res accumulation of ....... in the blood.

questionText: A 56years old male presents to the hospital with complains of chest pain which began 3 hours price to his visit and feels like a squeezing soji Which of the following findings or clinical presentations would increase the likelihood of Myocardial Infarction in this patient?

questionText: A 6 years old girl from the rural area was brought to your facility by her mother with complains of child not able to play with peers and always squatting after a short period of activity. Per your assessment you observed that the child had clubbed fingers. In your understanding you know that clubbing of the fingers occurs in which of the following conditions?
rationale: Clubbing of the fingers is a medical condition in which the fingertips become enlarged and the nail bed becomes curved, giving the fingers a club-like appearance. It is commonly associated with several conditions including congenital heart disease, lung cancer, and other conditions that result in chronic hypoxia or low oxygen levels in the blood.

questionText: A 64-year-old man reports to the emergency room with a severe headache that began 5 hours ago as a unilateral dull ache over his left eye and temporal region accompanied by nausea and photophobia. He took acetaminophen followed by ibuprofen, without receiving treatment for acute low back pain. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient due to cardiovascular concerns?
rationale: It is an opioid drug that has the potential to cause cardiovascular effects such as increased heart rate and blood pressure, which can exacerbate the patient's existing cardiovascular issues and potentially lead to adverse events like heart attack or stroke.

questionText: Which of the following is TRUE regarding C. Difficile?

An anaerobie gram-negative, spore-forming, toxin-producing bacillus.

rationale: C. Difficile is an anaerobic gram- negative, spore-forming, toxin-producing bacillus, and it is commonly associated with the use of antibiotics, which disrupt the normal gut microbiota and allow C. Difficile to proliferate and cause infection. It is transmitted via the faccal-ocal route and is not typically transmitted via airborne transmission.

questionText: A patient diagnosed with meningitis a cheduled for Lumber puncture. The nune explained to the patient that the spinal puncture needle will be introduced in between the
rationale: Rationale: During a lumbar puncture, a spinal puncture needle is inserted through the skin and tissues of the lower back and into the spinal canal to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for testing. questionText: A patient is admitted to the ward with the diagnosis of hypocalcaemia. During assessment, the patient began twitching on the facial muscles as a response to tapping of the facial nerve. This characteristic sign of hypocalcaemia is
rationale: The twitching of the facial muscles in response to tapping of the facial nerve is known as Chvostek's sign, which is a characteristic sign of hypocalcaemia due to the increased neuronal excitability that occurs as a result of low levels of calcium.

questionText: A patient is admitted to your ward with the history of hemoptysis, weakness and cough. Which of the following respiratory disorders is the patient likely to be diagnosed of?

questionText: A patient is on admission on your ward with pericarditis. The following could be the causes of his condition. I. Infections II. Brain injury III. Renal failure
rationale: Pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium, the fluid-filled sac that surrounds the heart, and can be caused by various factors such as infections and renal failure, causing chest pain and other symptoms.

questionText: A patient is on admission on your ward with pericarditis. The following could be the causes of his condition. I. Infections II. Brain injury III. Renal failure
rationale: Pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium, which is the sac-like membrane that surrounds the heart. It can be caused by infections and renal failure, but not brain injury, which is not commonly associated with pericarditis.

questionText: A patient is on the ward with haemolytic jaundice. Which of the following is the Nurse likely to observe in this patient?

questionText: A patient is to receive 3000ml of IV fluid in 12 hours. The drop factor is 10gtt/ml. To regulate the flow, how many drops per minute approximately, should the flow be?
rationale: To calculate the drops per minute (gtt/min), we can use the following formula: gtt/min (Volume to be infused x Drop factor)/ Time in minutes In this case, the volume to be infused is 3000 ml. and the time is 12 hours, which is equal to 720 minutes. So, $gtt/min=(3000	imes10)/720=41.67$ Therefore, the flow rate should be approximately 40 to 42 drops per minute (option C).

questionText: Madam Abena Manu, 64 years old, with the history of an overdose of aspirin tablets was brought to the OPD by her son. Which of the following is consistent with acute aspirin toxicity?
rationale: Aspirin toxicity can lead to respiratory depression because the drug inhibits the production of prostaglandins, which play a role in maintaining normal breathing, leading to decreased respiratory function and potentially fatal respiratory depression.

questionText: Madam Adwoah Mose, a 59 year old woman reported to the unit with her husband and two daughters with the complaints of chocking and a heavy sensation in the upper chest. She described the chest pain as sharp radiating to the neck, jaw and shoulders, subsiding when she is at rest in the couch. She was apprehensive and felt she was going to die. She was diagnosed of Stable Angina. The Nurse is educating the family of Madam Adwoah Mose on her condition. Which of the following statements by a family member require further teaching?
options: Achieve and maintain normal blood pressure
1 need to hold on to my daily walle since it aggravate my pain.
Alternate activities with periods of rest
rationale: This statement requires further teaching because physical activity is usually beneficial for stable angina patients, not something that would worsen the symptoms,

questionText: Madam Akosua Ansch was diagnosed of Hypokalemia and placed on Tablet Show K 20mg daily. While teaching Madam Ansah on her medication, Nurse Akowush encouraged her to.
options: Take each dose with a meal and a full glass of water.
Monitor pulse and blood pressure before and after taking medication.
Crush or chew the tablet before swallowing for quicker absorption,
rationale: This will improve absorption of the medication and reduce gastrointestinal side effects, as opposed to crushing or chewing the tablet.

questionText: Madam Akosua Omari was diagnosed with Leukaemia. Patients suffering from leukaemia are nursed in protective isolation because;
options: To prevent the transmission of infection via formites.
To increase their resistance to microorganism.
Because their immune system cannot react to microbial invasion.
rationale: This is to reduce the risk of infection, as the disease can impair the immune system and make it difficult for the patient to fight off infections.
